Description: Terracotta portable cooking stove fragment. Mould-made front of bearded face. Square upright projection from the rim on which is an ivy crowned male head in relief, the long beard extending inward to form a knob. A theatre mask of Dionysos, wreathed with ivy, and with a striated beard, within a rectangular panel. Above, Greek makers inscription EKATAIOY. The back is plain; part of the fire-bowl and its wide everted rim survive. The support and panel were made in a one-piece mould. Coarse gritty clay, dark red, without glaze.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel, probably from same mould series in Alexandria Museum (Didelot 1998, 286-7, fig. 1), close Egyptian 3rd to 2nd century BC parallel (Bayer Niemeier 1988, no.764. Published in Fairbanks 1928, p. 134, pl. XL, no. 378.2. Hekataios is a known Knidian portable stove maker of the late 2nd century BC, possibly producing into the early 1st century BC with many parallels from Halicarnassus, produced in Knidos (Şahin 2001, 95, Fig 13, no. Ha 9). Bayer Niemeier , E. 1988, Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann / Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik Frankfurt am Main I. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten, Melsungen. Didelot, O. 1998. Réchauds hellénistiques du Musée Grécoromain d'Alexandrie: Importations et productions locales, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 275-306. Fairbanks, A.1928, Catalogue of Greek and Etruscan Vases, Boston.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p.134, pl. XL, no. 378.2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (LA.04) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
